name: Maybe I'm just plain outta my head...
author: Noctem

posts.author: Noctem
posts.content:
...but I'm fixated on playing a Barb/Bard combo of some sort that actually uses CHA and doesn't see Bard as just a toehold into RDD-hood. I want someone with charm, someone with smarm, someone who can do great bodily harm. It all started when I had a high fever and saw a vision of a wandering barbarian who was so foreign to civilized society and, unintentionally, intimidating because of it that he figured he'd have to sing his own damn songs if he ever wanted an epic composed about his exploits.

I'm too old to be a n00b, but the moniker fits nonetheless. I played NWN OC when it first came out on disks, and dabbled in SoU/HotU when they too were in their infancy. Now that EE has arrived, I've been hooked all over again. I'm only playing PvM for now (OC is garbage but boy do I love Aielund so far) but I'd love to take a toon up to 40 somewhere/somehow and maybe even experience some PW action. I'm a huge fan of Mick, Valerfor, Max, and Stag's builds on here (can anyone say Paragon of Pain?!?) but that's not exactly how I'm vibing on this guy. He doesn't need to be evil, in fact I'd prefer if he isn't, so BG is right out. Barb/Bard/RDD but not the typical 28/2/10 build, more Bard in there? Something else altogether? Am I insane in the membrane for wanting this? Would it even work? Is there a way to make something *close to* truly epic out of this fever dream? Can one or more or all of you seasoned veterans help a brotha out?

posts.author: Noctem
posts.content:
Ooops, so I noticed that I totally neglected to follow the post guidelines and actually put all the info you might need... /smh been a long day and I'm excited as a kid in a candy store to finally post here.

Take 2
1) PvM or PvP - PvM for now, but with the idea that I wouldn't mind trying some PvP one of these aeons.

2) Level cap - 30 to 40 would be great (though I generally re-roll at 7-8 out of some sad addiction to character creation, but I hope this will be like an inoculation against that particular affliction).

3) Race preference - Furthest thing from my mind. Half-Orc for flavor maybe, but Human would probably be better all-around since I don't want CHA as a dump stat on this one.

4) Class preference - Barb + Bard + surprise me = wandering minstrel of smashbashiness.

5) Melee preference - 2 Handed weapon (greataxe maybe?), or sword & board; I could probably enjoy either. The 2-hander makes more sense from an Arcane Penalty perspective, but it isn't hard to remove/re-equip gear, especially since I expect he'll be a pre-buffer.

6) Range preference - Only cowards fight from afar; I want to sing right a little ditty right in your grill as I smash it in.

7) Weapon preference - Oh, did I answer #5 wrong? Greataxe, Greatsword, Heavy Flail or Scythe (depending on module/PW).

8) Maximum item enhancement - No clue, I'm wide open to where I play.

9) Spellcasting - Probably just buffing, but again, I'm open to alternate ideas.

10) Custom Factors - Probably, but since I'm not sure what sandbox I'll be peeing in, I don't know the answer to this question just yet.

Thanks!

This might not be terribly helpful, but I've had another thought...What about a Barbarian 15 or 19/ Bard 20 or 16/ Harper Scout 5? Again likely to be somewhat feat-starved (which was one reason I was thinking CoT - for the BFs), but if you take HS in epic levels you have a couple of potentially useful BFs available.

Of course, for an extra feat human would be advisable, but maybe a sort of wood elf or a Daelan-esque half-orc could cut it as well (elf if going for a Dex build, half-orc for a Str one). Let's have a think...Presumably you'll be wanting WF, KD, BFight, Imp Crit, WFinesse (if Dexing), Iron Will and Alertness (if going HS) as a minimum, and Terryfing Rage, EWF, Armor Skin and Epic Prowess in epic levels. Then there's the singing and spelling feats you'd want for Bard. If you fancied concentrating on the singing, that might help in feat terms, but many things are possible...

If you're looking at PvM up to level 40 (Aielund should get you to 36-37), there are various options open to you. The OC followed by the Mines of Twin Summit trilogy; the OC followed by Aribeth's Redemption then Sands of Fate; SoU and HotU followed by Sands of Fate; and there's solo World of Greyhawk.

Just a few musings for you

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
My apologies - I know how much I hate others using unknown (to me) acronyms. It's plain old-fashioned laziness on my part. In this instance, BFs are bonus feats, and in epic levels Harper Scout gets one at level 1 and another at level 5 - which is the maximum number of levels you can take in the class. You can use them for all sorts of things, including Favoured Enemy and Curse Song, Great Charisma, Great Dexterity and Lasting Inspiration, several of which could prove helpful in this concept. It's also a Tumble class, and can be really useful when you're in a bit of a hole, particularly if you're taking lots of levels in another class. (Pre-epic, only Favoured Enemy and Curse Song are available.) You do need the Iron Will and Alertness feats to qualify for the class, along with 4 ranks in Discipline, 6 in Lore, 8 in Persuade and 4 in Search - as well as being non-evil.

Hope this helps to clarify

How about a song-focused Bard 16/ Barbarian 16/ CoT 8 with stats (as a human) of STR 16 (30), DEX 10, CON 14, WIS 8, INT 14, CHA 14 (16)? I've yet to draw up a full schemata, but I reckon we can squeeze in (pre-epic) Lingering Song, Curse Song, Weapon Focus (let's go for Greatsword, shall we?), Improved Critical, Blind Fighting, Knockdown, Improved Knockdown (or Expertise or Heavy Armour Proficiency), Power Attack and Cleave (with 3 levels of CoT, 13 of Barbarian and 4 of Bard). Then in epic levels, 6 Great Strengths, Terrifying Rage, Epic Weapon Focus, Epic Prowess and Armor Skin. You'd take 8 natural strength bumps and 2 charisma ones.

We'd also have enough skill points to fully cover Discipline, Intimidate, Taunt and Tumble, one of Concentration or Spellcraft, sufficient Perform to hit 30 modified ranks, enough UMD to reach 33 modified ranks and a smattering of Lore or Listen (or Spot). All the saves should get over 20, and the BAB would be 29, and give a final AB of 43. The AC might be a bit sucky though.

What do you think? Shall I move ahead?

Cheers

posts.author: Noctem
posts.content: New question - why Lingering Song over Extra Music? Being somewhat nub-ish to Bards in general, is there an end-game reason that one is preferred over the other, such as longer boss-fights vs. not needing to cast it as often? Especially if doing the Bard Song/Curse Song in conjunction, it seems like more castings would be a good thing; but I'm not well-versed in the subtleties and intricacies of Epic Character building, which is why I'm here. :)

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Afraid in this instance it ain't subtleties and intricacies, it's maths.

Extra Music will give you 4 extra uses of song per day, so at level 16 you have 20 uses. Each use lasts 10 rounds, so that's a total of 200 rounds of song per day (or rest period).

Lingering Song adds 5 rounds to the length of each song, so each lasts 15 rounds. With 16 uses per day, that's a total of 240 rounds of singing per day (or rest period). Which is 40 more than with Extra Music.

So it's actually about getting more bang for your buck. Dull but true!

Cheers

EDIT: Of course, with the Lasting Inspiration feat, it becomes a largely redundant question, as each of your songs will last 100 rounds. But you need 20 levels of Bard for that (totalling 2,000 rounds per day, thus never really off) which we don't have here, sorry!

EDIT 2: As a general rule of thumb, Extra Music is the more useful feat up to Bard 8 ( a total of 120 rounds), when Lingering Song gives the same duration but fewer songs. Alas, you can't simply replace one with the other, so I was thinking long-term. You can, of course, swap when you take the Lingering Song and Curse Song feats in this build, but I thought Lingering was the more effective early choice.

posts.author: Stagmeister

To be honest, I went for a feat that could help with the fairly sucky AC (understanding that Song/Curse will help anyway, but Rage nullifies some of that). The Expertise/ Taunt combo is a happy by-product. However, I confess to being unclear how many things we can have active at one time - Song/ Curse/ Rage/ Expertise/ Taunt - I can't promise they'll all work together. I'm sure someone else will know...

A second confession, I also tend to skip on the Expertise feat (again, unless it's a build whose AC is a bit shonky) - something else always seems more worthwhile. However, on WoG, for example, it's almost compulsory to take it (and maybe its big brother as well). It's also very handy for those loons who play on hardcore rules (no offence, Mick and Mirnaia!). But for most modules it's a "nice to have" rather than "must have" feat, I find. Essentially, you'll stand less chance of dying at early levels - always handy - even if you're struggling to hit stuff, while at later levels and with (hopefully) arse-kicking AB, it's still very useful if you're taking too many hits.

Cheers

The Expertise/Taunt combo is a great way to improve AC and still keep AB, but you have to tap a lot on the keyboard to keep it active, since Taunt has a limited duration. It pays to do it against bosses and other very difficult foes.
The lazy version is to use Expertise alone to avoid being hit too much when swarmed by mobs, and deactivate it when their numbers dwindle somewhat.

posts.author: Mick Dagger

Stagmeister wrote: I just wonder if you know whether you can do everything at once - Sing, Curse, Rage, Taunt and be in Expertise mode?
Sorry, just got carried away
Taunt cancels Expertise. (That's what makes the timing of the T/E combo a bit tricky)
Activating Power attack cancels E.
Wielding a ranged weapon cancels E
Ending a fight cancels E.
Moving, other than attacking, cancels E.
Singing does not cancel E
Using Knockdown or Disarm does not cancel E
Casting depends on the server/mod settings
For Rage, I have not checked.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Stagmeister wrote: I tried having a look on the wiki about the Rage thing and got nowhere, so I simply googled the question...

And still got nowhere.
In Pen & Paper, the Barbarian is explicitly stated that he cannot use any skllis or feats that requires concentration or use of dexterity, intelligence or charisma during the time they are under the influence of rage. They also cannot use expertise or any meta-magic feats. Neverwinter Nights is more simplistic than that, so I created a Barbarian is PGC3 right now & checked it to be sure & it is as I suspecting it would be. Barbarians CAN use expertise without a problem even under the influence of rage, keep in mind that there is a slight delay (I suspect 1 round or less) before you can activate the feat if you have just used your rage ability.  
So the answer is, Yes you can.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
A lot will depend on where you're playing. In WoG, for example, AC is king, so definitely Expertise. In SoU/HotU (particularly HotU), the gear gets so OP it won't (well, it shouldn't) really make a difference either way. It depends more on play-style here - Expertise is about trying to avoid being hit, Toughness is more a recognition that you will be hit but can take it. Then there's Max's Taunt/Expertise trick if you're nimble enough on your keyboard (which I seldom am). I included Expertise primarily in this build because of the previously mentioned sucky AC, and at least Expertise could help with that. In other words, I felt guilty. Singing and Cursing might be just as beneficial, with no down-sides. And just to be really annoying, Disarm is another decent option, particularly with a 2-hander, but you should probably take its Improved cousin as well, so maybe not. In other words - your call!

Oh, and Power Attack can be helpful in its own right if you're playing a Dexer. Unless you have lock-picking skills you might never get some chests open without it, and it will help add damage in fights once your AB is high enough to hit reliably.

Cheers

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Thanks, mate!

Glad everything is going well. As far as the UMD is concerned, iirc you have 9 spare skill points to play with - you can always use 7 of those to boost your UMD to 37 (40) (there's not much point going further than that). Maybe it would have been more helpful to have pointed that out earlier - my bad, sorry! Still, you can drop a few more points in when you reach level 22, so not all is lost.

Yes, Enserric was indeed that very surprise, pleased he's working out for you. Now, what follows aren't really spoilers, but might help in how you approach your time in the Underdark. After you head out on your quests (5, iirc), you'll only be allowed back into Lith Myathar a couple of times before the big battle starts - and you won't have a say in that. There are several implications from this, not least of which is how many times you can get Riz to upgrade your stuff. Actually, while I'm on Rizolvr, if he detects that your weapon is already supercharged from other things, he won't upgrade it, so be sure you've done all the upgrades you want before using the black pearl(s) in Vix'thra's realm. (You will meet him again in Cania, but I'll leave it at that.).

However, the major deal from how many times you return to Lith Myathar is that any quests you haven't completed will come back to bite you on the bum. The battle's nasty enough without a bunch of Beholders or Mindflayers popping up in the middle of it. So, think strategically. There are several ways to do it so you can complete everything, but I'll give you the one that's worked out best for me. Do both islands before returning for the first time. If you start with Shaori's Fell, you can offload excess gear to the Duergar merchant on the Isle of the Maker. When you come back, you'll be richer than god, so can do more upgrades with relative ease. Then do 2 of the 3 quests in the Underdark proper (doesn't really matter much, but I tend to do the Undead and Mindflayers, because there's another merchant for offloading excess stuff to in the village as you approach Vix'thra's castle, and the Illithid merchant who will trade with you does have some of Nasher's gear, which can be quite kewl once you get all of it). Finally, it's the Beholders for me.

Oh, and try to get some protection from cold gear before you go to the final battle. Just saying.

Thanks for the update, and hope you don't mind the gentle advice - I know how frustrated I was the first time I played this bit.

Cheers

In SoF (chapter 2), there are enemies that can only be killed by acid damage, but melee is fine for those.  In chapters 2 and 3, there are other enemies that you don't want to hit with a melee weapon (similar to rust monsters), but they can only be damaged by fire or cold damage.  I explain which monsters these are in the spoiler.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: When I get to where the Knower of Names and those generals are imprisoned, I like to figure out where she is and shoot there last, so I can reap the experience points from all the generals.  Then, I save the game before freeing her.  If the Sleeping Man's true love is not her, I reload until it is.  Armed with her true name, I order her to go to him, and I also order her to give me Meph's true name.  Then, I can use Meph's true name to order him to die, with no need to fight him at all.  If you do that, make sure to equip the full set of Nasher's gear before talking to Meph, so it will be powered up when the game ends.  In SoF, they can't power back down when you unequip them.  That +7 STR ring is nice to have.
